Graphical Abstract Catalytic oxidation of 2-methylnaphthalene to 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone (vitamin K3) is a significant pathway to produce vitamin groups K. High pollution and low-productivity of the traditional method require a greener catalyst and process. In this work, Al/Ti-SBA-15 with different nSi/nAl and nSi/nTi ratios were hydrothermally prepared in mild acidic condition and tested in partial oxidation of 2-methylnaphthalene. Commercial zeolites NaY, β and ZSM-5 were applied to investigate the influence of mass transfer resistance and acidity on catalytic performance. Catalysts were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, TEM, NH3-TPD, FTIR and Py-FTIR. We have found that the 2-methylnaphthalene conversion and vitamin K3 selectivity depend strongly on the mesoporous structure as well as Brönsted acid concentration and strength. Irregular micropores and strong acidity will accelerate the cleavage of C = C in aromatic rings, leading to the production of phthalic anhydride. DFT calculation reveals that incorporation of aluminum in SBA-15 can reduce the energy gap, facilitating the electron transfer. And as a consequence of the substitution of Al in tetrahedral positions in SBA-15, Al-SBA-15 (10) gives the best result with 72% yield to vitamin K3. This catalyst markedly reduces the activation energy due to the modified activated center. Repeated experiments recommend that Al-SBA-15 is a steady and high-efficiency catalyst for the production of vitamin K3. Keywords Al/Ti-SBA-15 Catalytic oxidation Vitamin K3 DFT Kinetics 1 Introduction 2-Methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone (Vitamin K3) plays an important role in the blood coagulating on account of the anti-hemorrhagic properties [1,2]. It is also an essential raw materials to manufacture other vitamins K such as phylloquinone, menaquinone and acetomenaphthone, which is applied extensively in antineoplastic drugs, pesticides, and coating [3–6]. Traditionally, 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone (2-MNQ) is prepared on industrial scale from 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) by stoichiometric oxidation with chromium trioxide catalyst in sulfuric acid, the yield of 2-MNQ does not exceed 40∼50%. This route has many defects such as the heavy pollution of hexavalent chromium and waste acid [7–9]. Recent few years, there have been a lot of researches on the synthesis of 2-MNQ. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis were suggested to optimize the production method. And most routes begin with versatile 2-methylnaphthalene. Sorokin used CH3ReO3 as catalyst combined with 85% H2O2 solution and acetic acid, the yield of 2-MNQ is 47% [10]. But, the high concentrations of hydrogen peroxide pose a risk of exploding. System CrO3 with H5IO6 gave 61% yield for 2-MNQ [11]. Enomoto et al. describe PdII-polystyrene sulphonic acid resin as catalysts and offered 57.1% yield for 2-MNQ [12]. Chocron et al. electrochemically oxidized 2-MN to 2-MNQ with ammonium dichromate as catalyst, the selectivity for 2-MNQ was obtained > 60% with the 2-MN consumption of 60-70% per unit charge [13]. Moreover, transition metal complexes including vanadium [14], molybdenum [15], tungsten [16], palladium [17], lanthanum [18] and cerium [19] as well as phthalocyanine and metalloporphyrin [20,21] have been investigated in the production of 2-MNQ. Although these new methods and catalysts are good in the conversion of 2-MN, numerous defects cannot be ignored. As the 2-MNQ yield of these systems is around 40∼60%. Several catalysts become homogeneous during the reaction, resulting in the typical separation problems of target material from the media. Furthermore, a small amount of residual metals will cause contamination of 2-MNQ. In other reports, 2-methyl-1-naphthol was also been recommended as the substrate in place of 2-MN [3,22,23]. However, the price of 2-methyl-1-naphthol is much more higher compared with 2-MN and 2-MNQ, which limits its application in industry. The economics and the present day’s stringent environmental concerns require a greener, high-efficiency method to produce 2-MNQ from 2-MN. In this aspect, there is no question that heterogeneous catalysis is an eco-friendly process in the development of catalytic oxidation [24–26]. On the one hand, the reactants adsorb and react on the catalyst surface; adjustable physicochemical properties of solid catalyst make it more capable to converse reactant to target product. On the other hand, the catalyst can be separated from the reaction liquid by traditional filtration and centrifugation, which is beneficial to improve the product purity and reduce production cost. However, the study on steerable partial oxidation process is a rather arduous assignment. Usually, the target intermediates are more likely to participate in the reaction compared with the reactant. [27–30]. The oxidation of 2-MN to 2-MNQ can be regarded as a typical instance, for the C = C bond of aromatic ring is likely to cleave under certain conditions. This reaction is affected by strength of surface acid sites, type of acid sites, pore structure and reaction conditions. Therefore, a high yield of 2-MNQ demands a careful designed catalyst to reduce mass transfer resistance and selectively inhibit the secondary reaction [31–33]. Zeolites and mesoporous catalysts as acidic, basic and redox catalysts have been used in the petrochemical and oil refining. However, zeolites exist the mass transport limitation during the reactions for its microporous structure, especially when it comes to the large molecules reactions [34,35]. Currently, research on mesoporous materials has become a hotspot, especially SBA-15, due to its high specific surface area, narrow pore size distribution and hydrothermal stability [36,37]. While the inornate SBA-15 contains almost no acid sites, which restricts its application as catalyst [38,39]. So, SBA-15 is usually modified by incorporating several metal ions with redox properties for some special application. Al/Ti-substituted mesoporous SBA-15 is a typical example, their proper acidity combined with appropriate pore structure offer potentials for developing efficient catalysts for selective catalytic oxidation [40]. Aluminum atoms can be inserted into the SBA-15 walls by post and direct method. Vinu et al. have confirmed that the direct method combined with aluminum isopropoxide as Al precursor offers outstanding mesoporous structure and higher amount of aluminum incorporation [41]. And in most cases, the Al-substituted SBA-15 was synthesized at hydrochloric acid solution of pH 1.5, some are even less than 1.5 [42–45]. What these synthesized materials have in common is that the Lewis acid is dominant among the acid sites, which is not conducive to selective oxidation [46,47]. In keeping with the foregoing, it makes sense to investigate the catalytic activity of AlSBA-15 in the partial oxidation of 2-MN. However, to the best of our knowledge, the selective oxidation of 2-MN to 2-MNQ by using SBA-15 or Al/Ti-SBA-15 as catalysts has not been reported in the literature. And there are no reports regarding the effect of Brönsted acidity and pore structure on the oxidation performance of these catalysts. The aim of this work is to prepare Al/Ti-SBA-15 solids with higher concentration of Brönsted acid in moderately hydrochloric acid solution at pH 2.2 and to evaluate the catalytic behavior of SBA-15 and Al/Ti-SBA-15 on selective catalytic oxidation of 2-MN to vitamin K3, so as to study how the physic-chemical properties of the catalysts influence the catalytic activity. Commercial NaY, β and ZSM-5 were also investigated at the same conditions to evaluate textural limitation and acid effect. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pluronic P123 (EO20PO70EO20, Mn ∼5800) was supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, > 98%), Titanium butoxide (>98%) and Aluminium isopropoxide (99.99%) were provided by Aladdin biochemical technology co. Ltd., China. ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 20), NaY (Si/Al = 5), β (Si/Al = 25) were purchased from Nankai catalyst Company, Tianjin, China. Hydrochloric acid (37 wt. %) and hydrogen peroxide solution (30 wt. % in H2O) were purchased from Kermel Tianjin Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis Mesoporous SBA-15 was synthesized according to the process in literature [48]. Typical 4 g P123 intermingled with 150 mL HCl (2 M) was stirred for 4 h at 35 °C. Another amount of 8.5 g TEOS was dropped into the solution. After stirring for 24 h, obtained mixture was aged at 100 °C for 48 h in a stainless steel reactor with a Teflon lining. The obtained solid was vacuum filtrated from the mixture and calcined in the muffle furnace at 550 °C for 6 h. Mesoporous Al-SBA-15 and Ti-SBA-15 were manufactured through a direct hydrothermal method. Typical 4 g P123 and a certain amount of titanium butoxide or aluminium isopropoxide were mixed and stirred in 100 mL HCl (pH = 2.2), then adding 8.5 g tetraethyl orthosilicate into the solution and stirring it for another 24 h. Resulting white suspension was aged in the stainless steel reactor with a teflon lining at 100 °C for 48 h. The resulting product was separated and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The materials were labeled as Al-SBA-15 (n) or Ti-SBA-15 (n), where n denotes the Si/Al or Si/Ti ratio in the mixture. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The crystal form of the materials was identified by a Bruker X-ray Diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154 nm). Low-angle XRD was obtained from 0.5° to 5° with a step size of 0.01°. Wide-angle patterns were scanned between 8° and 80° with a step size of 0.02°. Physical absorption of nitrogen was measured by Quantachrome autosorb iQ2. The catalysts were vacuum heated at 300 °C for 4 h. Then, the characterization was carried out with high purity nitrogen at −196 °C. The specific surface area was calculated through Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Particle sizes of SBA-15, Ti-SBA-15 (10) and Al-SBA-15 (10) were measured by a laser particle size analyzer (Mastersizer 3000). Transmission electron microscopy of the catalyst was measured by using Tecnai G20 instrument. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption was performed by Micromeritics Autochem-2920. The sample tube was loaded with 0.1 g catalysts and heated at 500 °C for 1 h in He atmosphere. NH3 gas (20% NH3 in He) was then introduced for 1 h. NH3 desorbed from the catalysts was determined in the temperature range of 80 to 550 °C with heating rate 10 °C/min. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was measured via BRUEKR Tensor II spectrometer. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy was measured on Shimadzu 8300 spectrometer. A certain amount of catalyst was put into an in situ pool and was evacuated at 450 °C for 2 h. After that, catalysts were exposed to pyridine atmosphere; corresponding infrared spectra was collected when degassing temperature rises to 150 °C and 350 °C respectively. Adsorbed pyridine concentration on Lewis and Brönsted acid site was calculated by: (1) C ( pyridine on L sites ) =1.42∙IA(L)∙ R 2 / W (2) C ( pyridine on B sites ) =1.88∙IA(B)∙ R 2 / W Where IA(L) and IA(B) is the integrated absorbance of corresponding Lewis and Brönsted band (cm-1); R is the radius of catalyst disk; W is the weight of disk. 2.4 Catalytic activity Selective oxidation experiments were carried out in three necked flasks that heated by oil bath. During the reaction process, catalyst (0.05-0.2 g), 2-MN (0.3 g) and acetic acid (10 mL) were taken into the flask. The mixture was homogenized by a magnetic stirrer. H2O2 (6 mL, 30%) was added dropwise into the mixture when the temperature reached the set value. The stirring speed was 750 rpm to remove the effect of mass transfer (Fig. S1). After 2 h, the obtained produces were filtered and analyzed quantitatively by gas chromatography Agilent 7890B. The capillary column was Agilent HP-5 with 0.25 μm film thickness). Injector Temperature: 200 °C; FID detector temperature: 200 °C. 2.5 Computational details As a supplement to the experimental results, density functional theory (DFT) was widely used in calculating physical and chemical properties of catalysts [49–51]. In this work, the electrostatic potential and orbital property of SBA-15 and Al-substituted SBA-15 were calculated via Accelrys Material Studio Dmol3 module. The geometry of SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15 was optimized by generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional form [52]. The valence orbitals of the C, H, O, Si and Al atoms in this work were designed by DNP basis set [53]. The convergence criterion of self-consistent-field calculation was 1 × 10-6 Hartree, and the tolerances of energy, maximum force, and maximum displacement were 1 × 10-5 au, 0.002 au and 0.005 au, respectively. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis X-ray diffraction of β, ZSM-5 and NaY are shown in Fig. 1 (a). Main peaks at 7.8°, 9.4°, 12.8°, 20.8°, 23.1°, 23.6°, 24.3°, 25.6°, 26.6° and 28.6° correspond to the standard peaks of ZSM-5 zeolite (JCPDS PDF#44-0003). Characteristic diffraction peaks attributed to NaY are located at 2θ = 6.2°, 10.2°, 11.9°, 15.6°, 18.7°, 20.4°, 22.8°, 23.6°, 27.0°, 30.7° and 31.3° (JCPDS PDF#43-0168). And the main diffraction peaks at 2θ of 7.6°, 13.4°, 14.4°, 21.2° and 22.4° are ascribed to typical β (JCPDS PDF#48-0074). These peaks confirm the different crystalline structures of three zeolites. The patterns of SBA-15, Al-SBA-15 (5, 10, 20, 30) and Ti-SBA-15 (10, 20) are shown in Fig. 1 (b). There exist three obvious peaks at 2θ of 0.8°-2° for SBA-15, which is in accord with the (100), (110) and (200) reflections that are a prominent feature of the hexagonal space symmetry (P6mm) [54]. The obtained XRD patterns of Al-SBA-15 and Ti-SBA-15 are almost similar to the SBA-15, representing that the incorporation of Al and Ti atoms into SBA-15 framework does not change its hexagonal symmetry structure. But, it is noting that when more aluminum was added, the diffraction peak signal becomes weak. For example, Al-SBA-15 with Si/Al = 5 shows the disappearance of diffraction peaks corresponding to (110) and (200) planes; this result confirms that when excessive aluminum was inserted into the SBA-15 walls, the hexagonal symmetry of this materials will be destroyed, which is similar to literature reports [55]. 3.2 N2 adsorption-desorption studies Figs. 2 and 3 compare the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore size distributions of ZSM-5, NaY, β, SBA-15 and Al/Ti-SBA-15. The calculated textural properties, surface area, pore volume and average pore size are given in Tables 1 and 2 . All the three commercial zeolites exhibit evident hysteresis loop in a high P/P0 region, which appears to have mesoporous system characteristic. In addition, a steep step appears in the relatively low P/P0 zone, representing a typical microporous system. ZSM-5, NaY and β zeolites also exhibit features of type IV isotherm and H4 hysteresis loop; this can be ascribed to the existence of nonrigid aggregation of flaky particles or assemblages of slit-shaped pores. From Fig. 2, pore size distribution curves show that all commercial zeolites display hierarchical porous structures. It contains micropores with the pore diameter of 0-1 nm and the mesoporoes with the pore diameter of 2-4 nm. β shows the largest average pore size among them and the main channel diameter of it is around 0.56-0.75 nm. Synthesized SBA-15 and Al/Ti-SBA-15 overall perform typical type IV isotherms, while there are some differences in types. The hysteresis loop for SBA-15 shows a characteristic H1 hysteresis loop, suggesting SBA-15 has the uniform and cylindrical mesopores structure. However, with the increase in aluminum content, the hysteresis loop shape of Al-SBA-15(5) has transformed, it exhibits characteristic H3 type hysteresis loop. This phenomenon can be attributed to the pore expansion resulting from aggregation of platy shaped particles or sectional blockage of pores. For Al/Ti-SBA-15 samples, a phenomenon can be observed from pore size distribution patterns, corresponding points at which a sudden increase in the adsorption volume were delayed from 0.6 to 0.65, indicating pore broadening. From Fig. 3(b), all the prepared mesoporous materials show a narrow pore size distribution. As can be expected, the aluminum-substituted SBA-15 displays larger pore sizes (6.47-11.80 nm) in comparison with the pure siliceous SBA-15 sample (5.08 nm). In addition, with the increase of Al content, the average pore size increases gradually. Arguably, all of the composite materials exhibits lower S BET compared with the SBA-15 sample, what is a result of preparation procedure involving the metal incorporation. The S BET of Al-SBA-15 shows a monotonically decreasing trend with an increasing Al or Ti content. This variation is in keeping with previous reports: the decrease can be ascribed to the existence of metal oxide species inside and outside the mesopores of SBA-15 with the increase of metals [41,42]. While the pore volume decreases with the reduction in aluminum content. The Titanium incorporation has the similar situation. XRD and N2 adsorption-desorption analysis demonstrate that synthesizing well-organized aluminum-substituted SBA-15 mesoporous materials at high aluminum concentrations by direct hydrothermal method at a pH around 2.2 is difficult. One reason may be that aluminum precursor (Aluminium isopropoxide) is more easily hydrolyzed in the media of pH 2.2. The addition of large amounts of aluminum will accelerate the hydrolysis reaction resulting in the formation of large amounts of Al-O-Al, this further lead to the creation of non-framework aluminum. On the other hand, the interaction between condensing silicate species and the template P123 determines the hexagonal space symmetry morphology of well-ordered materials. A large number of aluminum precursors will also disrupt this interaction. So there is a lot of amorphous oxide in the product [56,57]. 3.3 TEM results The presence of a hexagonal and regular array of uniform channels is also identified by TEM characterization. Top images in Fig. 4 are perpendicular to pores axis and bottom images are parallel to the pore axis. From Fig. 4, three samples show no dark item in the middle of the framework of SBA-15, illustrating there exist no non-framework metal oxide in the ordered channels. The prepared Al/Ti-rich SBA-15 samples all preserve well-ordered hexagonal arrays of mesopores with one-dimensional channels indicating a 2D hexagonal (p6mm) mesostructure, which is also confirmed by XRD and N2 adsorption-desorption results. 3.4 FTIR The FTIR spectra patterns of synthesized SBA-15 and Al/Ti-SBA-15 are presented in Fig. 5 . The main band at ∼1070 cm-1 together with a shoulder at ∼1220 cm-1 can attribute to asymmetric Si-O-Si stretching modes. The weak band at 800 cm-1 is assigned to the intrinsic vibration of the TO4 tetrahedra containing Si and Al (Ti). An obvious band at around 460 cm-1 can be ascribed to bending vibration of Si-O-Si. It is worth noting that the weak band at ∼960 cm-1 gradually disappears with addition of aluminum or titanium in SBA-15. This phenomenon can be interpreted as the condensation process of Al or Ti species with the Si-(OH) terminal groups when introduce metal atoms into the mesoporous framework [58]. 3.5 TPD of NH3 Fig. 6 (a) displays NH3 desorbed profiles of the three zeolite catalysts. For ZSM-5, the pattern displays two bands at temperature 200 °C and 450 °C, representing weak and strong acidic sites, respectively. Samples NaY and β shows two desorption bands at temperature around 180 °C and 330 °C, ascribable to weak and medium-strong acidity. Among the three zeolites, ZSM-5 exhibits the higher number and strength of strong acid site when compared to NaY and β. While NaY contains high concentration of weak acid sites. The NH3-TPD curves of the prepared SBA-15 and Al/Ti-substituted SBA-15 are patterned in Fig. 6 (b). There exist no obvious bands for pure silicic SBA-15, this represents the synthesized SBA-15 shows very weak acidity in comparison to Al-SBA-15. For aluminum incorporating SBA-15, all samples show one main ammonia desorption peak which contains weak and medium acid site within the test temperature range. This may due to the atomic level aluminum atoms are highly scattered throughout the SBA-15 framework. From Fig. 6 (b), the total acidity increase as the decrease of Si/Al (increase in aluminum content). It’s worth noting that catalyst Al-SBA-15(Si/Al = 10) contains highest acidity, a further addition of aluminum leads to the decrease in acidity. The incorporation of aluminum can increase the concentration of weak and moderate strength acid sites (Brönsted), which is attributed to terminal hydroxyl connected tetrahedral coordinated Al and Si atoms in the framework [59]. The results for Ti-SBA-15 show that incorporation of titanium in SBA-15 tends to increase weak acid sites content relative to medium acid sites. Furthermore, both in terms of quantity and strength of acid, Al-SBA-15 has many more advantages than Ti-SBA-15. 3.6 Py-FTIR In order to assess the types as well as strength of acidity of Al-SBA-15 catalysts, IR spectroscopy for pyridine adsorption was applied, on account of the formation of various chemisorption sorts of pyridine ions with typical acid sites. Py-FTIR patterns of Al-SBA-15 catalysts with different aluminum content from 1700 to1400 cm-1 are shown in Fig. 7 . The quantitatively calculated distribution of acid sites according to Py-FTIR spectra are listed in Table 3 . The characteristic bands at 1454 and 1621 cm-1 belong to pyridine bounded to the strong Lewis acid sites [60], and the characteristic bands at 1545 and 1635 cm-1 can be assigned to pyridinium ion adsorbed on the Brönsted acid site [61]. Besides, band at 1490 cm-1 is ascribed to the vibrations of pyridine bounded to both Lewis and Brönsted acids site [62]. Generally speaking, subsistent Lewis acid sites are considered arise from the aggregation of octahedral coordination aluminum oxide that forms the non-framework aluminum species or the tri-coordinated framework aluminum [63]. Whereas the presence of Brönsted acid sites and its strength are associated with the tetrahedral aluminum present in the Al-SBA-15 structure [55,64]. According to Trombetta, the Brönsted acid roots in the terminal hydroxyl group that connects atoms of silicon and aluminum in the Al-SBA-15 walls. [65]. Py-FTIR analysis reveals the type of acid that is present the most is found to be Brönsted acid site. In addition, the bands area of Lewis (1454 cm-1) and Brönsted acid (1545 cm-1) increase with the decreasing Si/Al ratio and peak at Si/Al = 10. With lower Si/Al ratio, the band area of both Lewis and Brönsted acid reduces. These features point out that improved Al content can enhance the acid concentration especially for the Brönsted acid. Py-FTIR spectra of catalysts degassing at 150 °C and 350 °C were collected to evaluate the acidity of Al-SBA-15. Results show that the signal peaks of Brönsted and Lewis acid at 1545 and 1454 cm-1 still exist as the degassing temperature rises to 350 °C, which means Al-SBA-15 contains a certain number of relatively strong acid sites. But the area of bands of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites at 350 °C is less than those at 150 °C, suggesting that the number of strong acid is lower than that of weak acid. Combing the current NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR analysis, Al-substituted SBA-15 with Si/Al ratio = 10 has the highest acidity (both in concentration and strength). Higher aluminum content generates large amount of disordered coordination aluminum species and result in the decline of Brönsted and Lewis acidity. This could be due to the generated separate domains of alumina. Previous studies suggested that although Al-substituted SBA-15 process a good deal of tetrahedral even octahedral aluminum, the Brönsted and Lewis acid sites generate based on a few of these aluminum atoms [66,67]. These convincingly indicate the importance of the pore orderliness for the reservation of the acid sites. What is noteworthy is whether at 150 °C or 350 °C, the concentration of Brönsted acid and its strength is much higher than concentration and strength of Lewis acid. This could be due to the mild synthetic environment (at a pH level of 2.2), which is different from the literatures values (at a pH lower than 1.5). This shows that the preparation environment of the Al-substituted SBA-15 exert a noticeable effect on Brönsted acid. From the point of view of primary mechanism, the formation of Al-SBA-15 obeys the following mechanism: (S°H+)(X-I+). This means the charge-associated alkylene oxide units and the cationic silica species are combined through the electrostatic, hydrogen bonding and van der Waals force [41]. For incorporating Al into SBA-15 is the process: silanol groups are condensed with the partially hydrolyzed Al( H 2 O) 6 3+ species, for instance, Al(H2O)5(OH-)2+. In high acidic environment, the aluminum precursor hydrolyzes and is primarily exist as Al( H 2 O) 6 3+ form; this cut off the co-condensation between aluminum and silanol groups [68]. So, several aluminum atoms in the gel cannot be inserted into SBA-15 walls. 3.7 DFT calculation DFT calculation was used to further investigate the changes in SBA-15 electronic properties after inserting aluminum. Fig. 8 displays the electronic potential diagrams about SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15. Red region as the great positive concentration area reveals the acidity. While blue region is the great negative area where the positive charge can easily interact with it. For SBA-15, bridging oxygen and hydroxyl oxygen have large negative electrostatic potential, acting as base sites. Si and the hydroxyl hydrogen act as the acid sites. After incorporation of aluminum, the surface of catalyst shows low positive electrostatic potential and the aluminum becomes the positive center. On the basis of frontier molecular orbital theory, HOMO and LUMO are the critical factor to determine where the chemical reaction occurs. HOMO acts as an electron donor while the LUMO has the property to get electron [69]. Fig. 9 exhibits the calculated frontier molecular orbital and the corresponding orbital energy. The HOMO of SBA-15 and Al-SBA-15 are mainly consisted of the 2p orbital of the bridging oxygen and silicon hydroxyl oxygen. The bridging oxygen and hydroxyl oxygen atoms contribute the most for HOMO, which illustrate that as the center of base, these oxygen atoms have strong reducing property. As regards SBA-15, the Si atom, bridging oxygen and silanol mainly contribute the composition of LUMO. However, for Al-SBA-15, the LUMO is mainly donated by Al atom bridging oxygen and silanol hydrogen. The LUMO energy of Al-SBA-15 is -0.056 eV, which is lower than that of SBA-15 -0.046 eV. In addition, compared with SBA-15, Al-substituted SBA-15 contains a smaller energy gap, which means catalyst Al-SBA-15 has a higher chemical activity. 3.8 Catalytic performance Selective oxidation potentials of 2-MN to vitamin K3 over synthesized mesoporous SBA-15 and Al/Ti-SBA-15 were first explored in this work. ZSM-5, NaY and β zeolites were also examined as a comparison. Typical 30% H2O2 was used as an oxidant, and its concentration was determined by titration. Selective oxidation of 2-MN always be accompanied by over oxidation and/or oxicracking reaction. Generally, the reactant 2-MN is transformed to 2-MNQ, 6-MNQ, phthalic anhydride and a small number of 4-methylphthalic anhydride. Given the complexity of the oxidation of 2-MN, acetic acid has been chosen as the most suitable solvent. For the usage of other solvents tend to generate more side products and intermediates, which had been studied by previous literatures [22,70]. The results of catalytic activity evaluation are shown in Fig. 10 . Under similar conditions, the increased activity of applied catalysts obeys the sequence: β < SBA-15 < NaY < Ti-SBA-15 < ZSM-5 < Al-SBA-15. As was expected, aluminum incorporated SBA-15 catalysts exhibit the excellent performance, especially for Al-SBA-15 (Si/Al = 10); it shows the optimal reactivity with 100% conversion to 2-MN as well as 72% selectivity to vitamin K3 (side products are 10% phthalic anhydride, 16% 6-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone and 2% 4-methylphthalic anhydride in selectivity). By comparison with the main literature before (Table S1), Al-SBA-15 (10) is also an excellent catalyst in partial oxidation of 2-MN to vitamin K3. When use ZSM-5 as catalyst, despite of high conversion, the yield of 2-MNQ over ZSM-5 is much poorer than aluminum/titanium substituted SBA-15. Considering one fact that the concentration and strength of acid sites for ZSM-5 are much higher than those for Al-SBA-15, we can say that the development of selectivity does not purely rely on the increasing acidity. The non-positive correlation probably because the conversion and selectivity of a catalyst in this catalytic system are determined not only by total concentration and strength of acid sites but also by textural properties such as pore size distribution. Zeolite ZSM-5 proves 3D cross structure of straight tube channel and Z channel accompanied by really strong acidity, the uneven microporous structure may exert an influence on lowing selectivity to 2-MNQ. As 2-MN and 2-MNQ are the large molecules with the molecular diameter greater than 0.6 nm. The smaller pore system hinders the diffusion of 2-MN and quinone, therefore, it increase the residence time of quinone in pores what enhances the occurrence of further reactions. On the other hand, due to the really strong acidity, the reactant molecules will suffer a strong interaction with active species when they diffuse through the narrow channel, which will facilitate the overoxidation reaction, for instance, the C = C bond cracking reactions in aromatic ring structure. The diffusional limitation of reactant and product molecules in the micropores of ZSM-5 for longer duration as well as the strong acidity result in more nontarget products such as 6-MNQ and phthalic anhydride. While β contains 3D 12- membered ring microporous structure along with larger pore diameter than ZSM-5, the main channel diameters of β is only around 0.56-0.75 nm. As for NaY, although it has a larger specific surface area, the proportion of micropores is much larger among three zeolites. Besides, β and NaY have less acid sites, especially the Brönsted acid sites [71,72]. Defects in acidity combined with channel restraint lead to the worse performance of β and NaY. Synthesized Al-SBA-15 involving weaker acidity and more regular pore diameter than ZSM-5 gives the best catalytic behavior. Such weaker acidity prevents further oxidation of the target quinone, resulting in higher selectivity formation. In regard to Al-SBA-15 (x) catalysts, the conversion of 2-MN increases from 90% to 100% with the increasing aluminum content and reaches the peak at Si/Al = 10, and the selectivity of 2-MNQ increase from 58% to 72%. It proved the enhanced total acidity resulting from inserted aluminum atoms in the framework can improve both the conversion and selectivity in this catalytic system. The additional fact that catalyst Al-SBA-15 with Si/Al = 5 shows lower conversion and selectivity. This can be explained by partial blocking and deformation of pores as well as the absence of acid sites, which have been proved by characterization. According to pore size distribution and Py-FTIR results, one can conclude that aluminum-rich Al-SBA-15(10) and Al-SBA-15(20) possess parallel Lewis acidic numbers and strength; in addition, the channel diameters of them are large enough. Despite of their similarities, Al-SBA-15 (10) shows a better catalytic performance than Al-SBA-15(20). Therefore, it can be said that Brönsted acid sites contribute tremendously to improving performance. The conclusion is similar to that of cracking hydrocarbons [49]. So, we propose that compared with the Lewis acid sites, the Brönsted acid sites have more crucial effect on selective oxidation of 2-MN to vitamin K3. Under the same condition, maximum yield that can be achieved by Ti-SBA-15 catalyst is 51%. This comparatively poor yield can be associated with the lower concentration and strength of acid sites, which restricts the catalytic activity. Because of the best catalytic performance, Al-SBA-15 (10) was used for the further oxidation with different reaction parameters reaction temperature, time, amount of oxidant and catalyst to obtain the finest reaction conditions. The effects of different reaction temperature and time on the conversion and selectivity were shown in Fig. 11 . As the temperature rises from 70 °C to 100 °C, 2-MN conversion keeps going up and stays at 100%. While the selectivity of 2-MNQ increases and reaches its peak at reaction temperature 90 °C. This is probably because of the less activity of acid sites over the catalysts at low temperature. On the contrary, at higher temperatures, series deep oxidations become the dominance, such as the C = C cleavage reaction to generate anhydride, which results in a distinct decline in 2-MNQ selectivity. And as time goes by, the growth of 2-MN conversion and 2-MNQ selectivity is slowing. Fig. 12 (a) shows the catalyst quantity affecting on the catalytic performance. The selectivity of 2-MNQ climbs up and then declines with the increasing catalyst quantity. The improved selectivity can be ascribed to the increasing reactive sites. However, the cracking reaction will become dominant in the case of too many active sites. Data in Fig. 12 (b) shows the catalytic performances affected by the amount of H2O2. When the experiment is carried out with 6 mL H2O2, the catalyst shows the best performance. More hydrogen peroxide can maximize the conversion as well as result in the further oxidation of quinone. Moreover, the large amount of introduced water will occupy the active sites, thereby lower the catalytic acivity [73]. To achieve better insight into the reaction mechanism and identify the difference between Al-SBA-15 (10) and Ti-SBA-15 (10) catalysts, we studied the kinetics about these two catalysts. Effect of stirring speed on the oxidation of 2-MN over Al-SBA-15 (10) were evaluated and the results are shown in Fig. S1. It is found that the initial reaction rate increases with the increasing stirring rate. When the stirring rate reaches 750 rpm, the external diffusion limitation is considered eliminated. Average particle sizes of Al-SBA-15 (10) and Ti-SBA-15 (10) are 11.06 and 12.40 μm (Table 2), which is so small that the intraparticle mass transfer limitation can be ignored [74,75]. The reaction network of 2-MN oxidation is shown in Fig. 13 . Because H2O2 was quite slowly pumped into the reaction system, the change in volume fraction can be ignored. And the oxidation of 2-MN and methylphenol has been studied for first order process. So the kinetic equation can be expressed as: (1) r A =- ( k 1 + k 3 ) C A (2) r B = k 1 C A - k 2 C B (3) r C = k 2 C B (4) r A = k 3 C A (5) k = k 0 exp (- E a / RT ) Where A, B, C, D represent 2-MN, 2-MNQ, phthelic anhydride and 6-MNQ, respectively. k 0 is pre-exponential factor and E a is activation energy. Reaction rate constant k 1, k 2 and k 3 are calculated by MATLAB software, and the kinetic equations of 2-MN to 2-MNQ over Al/Ti-SBA-15 are listed in Table 4 . Corresponding Arrhenius plots are presented in Fig. 15. Both plots are linear; R 2 for Al-SBA-15 is 0.9927 and for Ti-SBA-15 is 0.9886. The slope of lines gives activation energy for Al-SBA-15 is 42.14 kJ/mol, while this value for Ti-SBA-15 is 50.36 kJ/mol. This indicates that addition of aluminum can better regulate the active sites by reducing the activation energy of the target reaction. Comparison between experimental and calculated concentrations of 2-MNQ are shown in Fig. 14 . Outcomes reveal that the kinetic equations can accurately express the change in the concentration of the target product over these two catalysts. Statistical test results are listed in Table 4. For nonlinear regression, when F > 10F 0.05 (Mp , M-Mp -1), the model is considered to be suitable for a reaction. Results in Table 4 illustrate the obtained models are applicable. To obtain the optimal process conditions and find the most remarkable effects among of the four above mentioned parameters, an orthogonal experiment was carried out. The experiments contain four factors (temperature, reaction time, catalyst amount, H2O2 amount) and four levels for each factor. The arrangements and results are listed in Table 5 . From orthogonal experimental, the influence level of each factor can be found out. In Table 5, M i represents the mean value of 2-MNQ yield for four reactions at level i. Outcomes suggest that reaction temperature has the most significant influence on 2-MNQ yield among the four factors, followed by reaction time and H2O2 amount. The catalyst amount has less influence on 2-MNQ yield. The corresponding intuitive analysis using statistical calculation based on the experimental data in Table 5 is performed in Fig. 16 . Through 16 experiments, the reaction temperature of 90 °C, the reaction time of 2 h, the catalyst amount of 0.1 g and the H2O2 amount of 6 mL were confirmed as the optimal reaction condition. The catalyst Al-SBA-15 (10) was reused in the oxidation of 2-MN to investigate the stability. Each recycle experiment will be repeated three times. After that, the catalyst was filtered, washed with acetone and was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. Then, 0.1 g catalysts were used under the same condition. The reused performance of Al-SBA-15 (10) was given in Fig. 17 (a). There exists a slight decline in 2-MN conversion and a little change in 2-MNQ selectivity. Characterizations including TEM, physical absorption of nitrogen and XRD of Al-SBA-15 (10) catalyst after the third recycling experiment are shown in Fig. 17 (b-e) and Table 2; results show that the mesopore size and pore volume of Al-SBA-15 (10) decrease slightly. While the catalyst still preserves well-ordered hexagonal arrays of mesopores with one-dimensional channels. Repeated experiments recommend that Al-SBA-15 is a steady as well as high-efficiency catalyst for the production of vitamin K3. According to characterization and experimental analysis, a possible mechanism for the oxidation of 2-MN to 2-MNQ over Al-SBA-15 was proposed in Scheme 1 . In general, aromatic system experiences an electrophilic aromatic substitution reaction. It have been investigated that the Ti-OH and Al-OH are highly reactive toward peroxides and favor the formation of titanium and aluminum hydroperoxo species as the active sites of oxidation reaction. For this reaction, the first step involves the reaction between Al-(OH)-Si and perxides to give silicon-aluminum peroxo species. This active species attack the aromatic ring at position 1 to create a new carbon-oxygen bond in a. the generation of b and c after electron transfer. Then, the active species react with position 4 of aromatic ring and give the intermediate d. This step is faster than the hydrolysis of c, which is supported by the fact, the yield of 2-MNQ reduces when the catalyst dosage decreases. The hydrolysis of d generates e, which is quickly oxidized to quinone f. 4 Conclusions In this study, various Al-SBA-15 and Ti-SBA-15 catalysts with changed Si/Al and Si/Ti ratio were synthesized through direct hydrothermal method in moderately acidic aqueous media and applied to the partial oxidation of 2-MN to vitamin K3, and compared to commercial zeolites NaY, β and ZSM-5. The investigation shows the Al-SBA-15 catalyst prepared in moderately hydrochloric acid solution at pH 2.2 contains large number of Brönsted acid sites and narrow pore size distribution. Maximum 72% yield of 2-MNQ was obtained by Al-SBA-15 (Si/Al = 10) catalyst, which is superior to catalysts reported by previous literatures. The catalytic performance about this reaction system was found to be straight correlated with acidity, especially, the concentration and strength of Brönsted acid. From this aspect, NaY, β, Ti-SBA-15 and pure silicic SBA-15 exhibit low conversion and selectivity. And at the same time, the textural properties of catalysts contribute greatly to the product distribution. Due to the enhanced diffusional efficiency of reactant and product molecules transferred in the channels, Al-SBA-15 has a higher selectivity of 2-MNQ. The irregular microporous system of ZSM-5 accelerate the reaction route to the direction of C = C cleavage. This proves the significance by combining Brönsted acidity and diffusion control in the selective oxidation of 2-MN to vitamin K3. DFT calculation has revealed that aluminum substituted SBA-15 has lower LUMO energy and smaller energy gap, which is in favor of electron transition. Kinetic equations were established through calculating pre-exponential factor and activation energy. E a value of oxidation 2-MN to 2-MNQ over Al-SBA-15 is significantly lower than that over Ti-SBA-15, indicating aluminum can better regulate the active sites. Moreover, an orthogonal experiment was designed to optimizing the reaction process. This study offers an alternative way for the development of a green and efficient reaction system to produce vitamin K3. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic oxidation of 2-methylnaphthalene to 2-methyl-1,4-naphthoquinone (vitamin K3) is a significant pathway to produce vitamin groups K. High pollution and low-productivity of the traditional method require a greener catalyst and process. In this work, Al/Ti-SBA-15 with different nSi/nAl and nSi/nTi ratios were hydrothermally prepared in mild acidic condition and tested in partial oxidation of 2-methylnaphthalene. Commercial zeolites NaY, β and ZSM-5 were applied to investigate the influence of mass transfer resistance and acidity on catalytic performance. Catalysts were characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, TEM, NH3-TPD, FTIR and Py-FTIR. We have found that the 2-methylnaphthalene conversion and vitamin K3 selectivity depend strongly on the mesoporous structure as well as Brönsted acid concentration and strength. Irregular micropores and strong acidity will accelerate the cleavage of C = C in aromatic rings, leading to the production of phthalic anhydride. DFT calculation reveals that incorporation of aluminum in SBA-15 can reduce the energy gap, facilitating the electron transfer. And as a consequence of the substitution of Al in tetrahedral positions in SBA-15, Al-SBA-15 (10) gives the best result with 72% yield to vitamin K3. This catalyst markedly reduces the activation energy due to the modified activated center. Repeated experiments recommend that Al-SBA-15 is a steady and high-efficiency catalyst for the production of vitamin K3.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient selective oxidation of 2-methylnaphthalene to vitamin K3 over mesoporous Al/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts: The effect of acid sites and textural property
